title: set theory - Distributivity of certain infinite products
body: Suppose we have a sequence of posets $\{\mathbb P_n : n\in\omega\}$ such that for each $n$ , $\mathbb P_{n+1}$ is $|\mathbb P_n|^+$ -distributive. Is $\prod_{n>0} \mathbb P_n$ necessarily $|\mathbb P_0|$ -distributive? set-theory lo.logic forcing posets infinite-combinatorics Share Cite Improve this question Follow edited Jun 16, 2020 at 20:01 YCor 67.5k 5 5 gold badges 203 203 silver badges 301 301 bronze badges asked Jun 16, 2020 at 19:30 Monroe Eskew 21.1k 5 5 gold badges 62 62 silver badges 130 130 bronze badges $\endgroup$ 4 1 $\begingroup$ Is the product a full support one? $\endgroup$ Asaf Karagila –  Asaf Karagila ♦ 2020-06-16 19:34:15 +00:00 Commented Jun 16, 2020 at 19:34 $\begingroup$ @AsafKaragila Jawohl. $\endgroup$ Monroe Eskew –  Monroe Eskew 2020-06-16 19:35:04 +00:00 Commented Jun 16, 2020 at 19:35 $\begingroup$ And when you say $\kappa$-distributive, do you mean the intersection of $\kappa$ dense open sets is dense, or that for any $\alpha<\kappa$ the intersection of $\alpha$ dense open sets is dense? $\endgroup$ Asaf Karagila –  Asaf Karagila ♦ 2020-06-16 19:36:05 +00:00 Commented Jun 16, 2020 at 19:36 2 $\begingroup$ The latter. It’s the “right” definition since $\kappa$-closed implies $\kappa$-distributive. $\endgroup$ Monroe Eskew –  Monroe Eskew 2020-06-16 19:38:18 +00:00 Commented Jun 16, 2020 at 19:38 Add a comment  |  0 Sorted by: Reset to default Highest score (default) Date modified (newest first) Date created (oldest first) You must log in to answer this question.
